Description: Mould-made scarab in glazed composition; back clearly and simply modelled with incised single lines, representing the features of clypeus, prothorax and elytra, with feathered legs at front; at side, legs well-modelled with undercut triangular space; underside decorated with representation of a recumbent lion facing right and sun-disc above its back; motif stamped rather than incised, encircled by groove near edge; longitudinally pierced; pale greenish turquoise glaze relatively well preserved on underside, but motif itself unglazed, maybe pale yellow originally (bichrome glazing: yellow motif on a turquoise background?); creamy white core, hard and fine in texture.
Curator's comments: The faience object was analysed by proton induced X-ray emission spectrometry (PIXE) under a 3 MeV energy proton beam for characterisation of the elemental chemical composition (major, minor and trace elements), in March 2014, by the Centre de Recherche et de Restauration des Musées de France (C2RMF). Scarabs with a lion motif depicted on the base belong to a standard group produced at the 'Scarab Factory' (on its various productions, see Webb forthcoming). Petrie illustrated a number of different versions (Petrie 1886, pl. 37, 34-45). This scarab belongs to a type which was widely distributed in the Mediterranean area and Southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 93, 95-96, type XXVIII A, subtype A49-72, especially A52 for this piece).
